references: Armstrong, D.M. 1977. Ecological distribution of small mammals in the Upper Williams Fork Basin, Grand County, Colorado. Southwestern Naturalist, 22:289-304.
Negus, N.C., and J.S. Findley. 1959. Mammals of Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy 40:371–381.
Hoffman, G.R. 1960. The small mammal components of six climax plant associations in eastern Washington and northern Idaho. Ecolgoy, 41:571-572.
Beer, J.R., P. Lukens, and D. Olson. 1954. Small mammals populations on the islands of Basswood Lake, Minnesota. Ecology, 35:437-445.
Pattie, D.L., and N.A.M. Verbeek. 1967. Alpine mammals of the Beartooth Mountains. Northwest Science, 41:100-117.

Gunderson, H.L. 1962. An eight and one-half year study of the red-backed vole (Clethrionomys gapperi Vigors) at Cedar Creek Forest, Anoka and Isanti Counties, Minnesota. Ph.D. Dissertation, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, 110 pp.
Iverson, S.L., R.W. Seabloom, and J.M. Hnatiuk. 1967. Small-mammal distributions across the prairie-forest transition of Minnesota and North Dakota. American Midland Naturalist, 78:188-197.
Rickard, W.H. 1960. The Distribution of small mammals in relation to climax vegetation mosaic in eastern Washington and northern Idaho. Ecology, 41:99-106.
Merritt, J.F. 1981. Clethrionomys gapperi. Am. Soc. Mamm.,Mammalian Species No. 146. 9 pp.
Clark, T. W. 1973. Local distribution and interspecies interactions in microtines, Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming. Great Basin Naturalist, 33;205-217.
Manville, R. H. 1949. A study of small mammal populations in northern Michigan. Miscellaneous Publications, Museum of Zoology, University of Michigan 43:1–83.
Williams, O. 1955. The distribution of mice and shrews in a Colorado montane forest. Journal of Mammalogy, 36:221-231.
habitat_description:
Great Plains:
From Merritt (1981):
C. gapperi frequents chiefly mesic habitats in coniferous, deciduous, and mixed forest with abundant litter of stumps, rotting logs, and exposed roots. In the West, habitats include forests of ponderosa pine, red and white cedar, hemlock, spruce, Douglas fir, and spruce-fir, grassy meadows, chapparal, willow-grass-sedge, rockslides, and krummholz (Williams 1955, Negus and Findley 1959, Hoffman 1960, Rickard 1960, Pattie and Veerbeek 1967, Clark 1973, Armstrong 1977). In the Midwest, C. gapperi occupies coniferous forests o f pine, cedar, spruce, balsam fir, hemlock, and tamarack, deciduous forest of maple, basswood, oak, aspen, and birch, mixed hardwoods, and thick brush (Manville 1949, Gunderson 1962, Beer et al. 1954, Iverson et al. 1967).
